entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: SAP Build FAQ: Commercials, Getting Started and More
entry.content:
This FAQ provides an overview of SAP’s commercial offering of SAP Build. It covers the available commercial models for SAP Build and provides answers to questions that we most often hear regarding SAP Build commercial model, onboarding, metering and more. 

What is the SAP Build Unified Offering?  

SAP Build has been designed as the optimal way to extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud and other business applications. Thousands of customers are already experiencing up to 3x faster development speeds with SAP Build according to recent analyst research — and now we’ve made it even better. 

Combined with deep technical integration, SAP Builds unified offering empowers customers to quickly extend and personalize their business solutions using AI-powered application development and automation, while maintaining a clean core and eliminating additional licensing or budgeting complexity. 

What is included in the Unified SAP Build Offering?  

 Customers can access the full range of SAP Build capabilities through just four distinct SKUs.  

  • SAP Build Base User is for end users who need to access applications, gain insights for day-to-day business needs, and approve tasks. 
  • SAP Build Premium User includes all the features of the base user license, with added capabilities for end users to author content, monitor processes, customize pages and deploy attended bots. 
  • SAP Build Developer includes all the features of the Premium User license, plus advanced capabilities for developers and architects who need full access to deployed assets. 
  • SAP Build Runtime Application hosting and lifecycle management services that support the creation and execution for dev/test as well as production environments 

How do I find out what is included in SAP Build?  

  • For a list of services that are included in SAP Build you can visit the SAP Discovery Center, for SAP Build following this link 
  • To find out what is in each SKU, Base, Premium, Developer and Runtime you can visit the SAP Build Pricing Page here. 

What commercial models are SAP Build provided in?  

Consumption Based Model:  

  • SAP BTP Enterprise Agreement (BTPEA) 
  • SAP Cloud Enterprise Agreement (CPEA) 
  • Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP 

Subscription Based Commercial Mode:  

  • Service Plan for SAP Build Subscription 

SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition:  

  • SAP Build Entitlements are included in the SAP Cloud ERP Edition 
  • Find more about SAP Cloud ERP Edition here   
  • Find out more about the SAP Build offering in SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition here 

SAP Business Suite Packages: 

  • Entitlements are provided in several of the SAP Business Suite packages 

Partner: 

  • SAP Build offers partners free access to SAP Build and other BTP Services. 
  • SAP Build Test, Demo Development (the site requires you to be logged in as an SAP Partner) 
     

How do I get started with SAP Build?  

SAP Build uses SAP BTPs Cloud Integration Automation (CIA) to quickly get customers and partners up and going on SAP Build.  Find information on how to setup SAP Build here.  For detailed instructions on the activation process, please share this blog post with your technical team 

Does SAP Build include Joule Studio and Joule for Developer?   

Yes, SAP Build provides Joule for Developer and Joule Studio.  Joule Studio is provided with the SAP Build Developer offering.  Joule for Developer features are included, but will need to enable this through the free voucher SKUs.  You can find more information on Joule for Developer here and Joule Studio here. 

Are there specific service plans that are exclusive to the unified SAP Build offering? 

The Joule Studio service is only offered in the SAP Build Developer SKU. Joule for Developer needs to be enabled through the free voucher SKU's and then can only be used with the SAP Build offering, SAP Build Code and Joule for Developer, BTP ABAP Environment.  Visual Cloud Functions in SAP Build Apps is not available in the SAP Build unified SKU. 

Can I migrate from the previous SAP Build SKU’s to the new SAP Build SKU?  
 
Upgrade you SAP Build licenses to access enhanced features and tools.  Use build-specific plans for improved efficiently and customization in your projects.   

For migration of services please refer to this help 

 Can I use both the Old and New Service plans within the same subaccount? 

 The old services cannot be enabled in the same subaccount as the new Build services.  You will need to do a migration per the above migration guide. 

 How does metering work, for example if I use both SAP Build Base User and SAP Build Developer capabilities? 

SAP Build operates on a metering model that relies on specific user roles to determine access and functionality within the platform, which include developer, base user, and premium user. Each user must have a global user ID created by an administrator, who also assigns the appropriate role collection to ensure that the correct authorization is granted. 

This role assignment is critical; for instance, an SAP Build base user shouldn't be able to create new processes within SAP Build, as such permissions could lead to unintended alterations or disruptions in workflows. By understanding and correctly implementing these roles, organizations can effectively manage user capabilities while maintaining the integrity and security of their SAP Build environment. 

For more detailed information on metering and roles visit this help location. 

 How can I learn more about SAP Build?  

  •  SAP Build Basic Trial–Get hands-on experience with a free, 30-day trial, following a step-by-step tutorial on SAP Build. 
  • SAP Discovery Center–Dive deeper with step-by-step guidance and best practices for implementing use cases.  
  • SAP Learning –Develop SAP skills for free, anywhere, anytime, and at your own pace: SAP Build

entry.title: Joule Skill for Maintenance Order Management in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog is created to showcase the Joule Skills feature in SAP and is intended for demonstration purposes only. The content is not meant for productive use.

This use case demonstrates the creation and deployment of Joule Skills in SAP Build to manage Maintenance Orders in SAP S/4HANA. By leveraging APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, the solution enables users to create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders through natural language interactions in Joule. The setup involves configuring input parameters, mapping them to action calls, and formatting responses, all while securely connecting the SAP BTP environment to the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system via Cloud Connector. This provides a seamless, conversational interface for maintenance order management, highlighting the capabilities of Joule Skills for process automation and intelligent interaction.

Prerequisite

  1. Establish a secure tunnel between the SAP BTP subaccount and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system in Cloud connector. This allows the Joule skill to communicate with backend services (such as the Maintenance Order APIs) hosted in the on-premise system.
  2. After configuring the Cloud Connector to establish connectivity between the SAP BTP environment and the on-premise SAP S/4HANA system, the next step is to create a destination in the BTP subaccount.
    This destination acts as a connection point that allows applications (such as Joule skills or process automation projects) to call on-premise APIs securely through the Cloud Connector.

Begin by creating a custom action and selecting the required API from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This API will be integrated into the Joule Skill to enable Maintenance Order Management through action calls. Once the action is created, choose the available operations. For this demonstration, the Maintenance Order – POST, UPDATE, and PATCH methods are used to perform create, update, and retrieve functions. After adding these actions, test each one using the test feature and select the destination configured in the BTP cockpit.

 

In SAP Build Lobby, create a Joule Skills project and provide a suitable description for the skill. For example:

Create individual Joule skills for Maintenance Order – POST/UPDATE and PATCH operations.

Create Maintenance Orders

Set up the input parameters for this Joule Skill, which will be used in the prompt during the demo of maintenance order creation from Joule. Next, create a destination variable to ensure the destination is correctly mapped upon project deployment. Map all necessary values from the input parameters to the respective inputs of the action call used for creating a maintenance order. Finally, proceed to the last step to format the response in Joule using the ‘Send Message’ option.

Get Maintenance Order – Joule Skill

Change Maintenance Order – Joule Skill (Same as above)

After this release and deploy the project in the environment.Once deployed the version is reflected and launch the Joule

So by deploying the created joule skills we now have this feature by using natural language.

In conclusion, this demonstration highlights how Joule Skills in SAP Build can simplify Maintenance Order Management by enabling intuitive, natural language interactions with SAP S/4HANA. Through seamless integration using the Cloud Connector and APIs from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub, business users can efficiently create, update, and retrieve maintenance orders without navigating complex interfaces.

Demo Link

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and Joule agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

As Skill Builder in Joule Studio is General Available, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question: "How to get Joule Studio?"

Whether you're a business decision-maker assessing impact, a developer organizing your technical landscape, or a partner helping your customer, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Before diving into the setup, it's essential to take a moment to review the commercialization details. It is crucial to ensure that you have the correct plans and SKUs in place for building and executing Joule Skills effectively. Understanding these components will set a solid foundation for a successful implementation.

Let's get started!

 

Pre-Requisites for Customers

SAP Build

    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.
    • The new unified SAP Build commercial model is now live across all four models: 
      • Subscription 
      • BTPEA - Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement (since August 11)
      • PAYG - Pay As You Go (since August 11)
      • CPEA - Cloud Platform Enterprise Agreement (NEW – September 17) 

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher) - Joule Base (SKU 8019544) or Joule Premium (SKU 8019164) (Includes AI Units)
    • Joule Studio works  with any Joule brownfield license, except Joule for Consultants and Joule for Developers.

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it’s important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free, the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation will still be billed according to the Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement pricing structure.

 

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Customer Starting Points and Required Steps

 This table outlines the five primary customer scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA  in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you’re starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The customer is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  • Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement/subscription is on the build-default plan (standard is not compatible).
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
 

Some Questions 

  • I don't have SAP Build! What to do? 
       Initial setup of SAP Build
  • Which license do I need to access Joule Studio? 
       SAP Build Default plan 
  • How can I upgrade my SAP Build Standard Plan to Build Default plan? 
       Change Plan
  • I don't have Joule! What do I do?

Expert Insights

  • If your existing SBPA is on a "Standard" plan, you must upgrade it to the "Build Default" plan before attempting to link it with Joule Studio.
  • Reference Architecture 
    In the picture below, Joule and SBPA are configured within the same subaccount. However, they can also be set up in different subaccounts or even across separate global accounts.
    But in case Joule and SBPA are both in different global accounts, this is also possible, but with the same Cloud Identity Service for both accounts.

entry.title: Unlocking Visibility with “No Correlation” feature in Process Visibility
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s fast-paced business world, not every process follows a straight path, or even connects at all. Yet, enterprises still need end-to-end visibility.

Enter SAP’s powerful capability in Process Visibility: the “No Correlation” feature.

Whether you’re managing HR workflows or procurement cycles, this feature offers flexibility to monitor and analyze non-correlated processes together — all within a single dashboard.

 

Why Does “No Correlation” feature Matter?

Not all business processes are tightly linked. Many operate in parallel within the same business domain but have no direct interaction.

Example:

  • Hiring vs. Retirement
  • Promotion vs. Equipment Provisioning

They all fall under Human Resources, yet they function independently. Still, business leaders need visibility across all these activities, ideally through one Visibility Scenario dashboard.

That’s exactly what Process Visibility's “No Correlation” feature enables.

 

Building the Foundation: Process Groups

SAP Process Visibility lets you group processes - correlated or non-correlated into Process Groups for better monitoring.

Two main configurations:

  1. Correlated Processes (e.g., Hiring ↔ Equipment Provisioning)
    • Processes are connected in sequence.
    • Define connections between them within a process group.
  2. Non-Correlated Processes (e.g., Promotion Change, Retirement)
    • Processes run independently but still need unified tracking.
    • Create separate process groups and map common attributes to view them cohesively.

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

 

Step-by-Step: Enabling Non-Correlated Process Tracking

  • Adding Process Participants:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor → Processes tab → Add the processes that need to either be correlated or not correlated, as process participants.

In this example, we have created a Visibility Scenario for HR Department. We are adding 4 processes as process participants – Hiring, Promotion Change, Retirement and Equipment Provisioning. In this scenario, Hiring and Equipment Provisioning are related processes, while Promotion Change and Retirement are independent processes.

  • Enable the No Correlation Feature

As we have processes that are not correlated, we will have to enable this feature.
In your Visibility Scenario Editor → General tab → Enable “Visibility Scenario to Include Non-Correlated Processes”

This unlocks side-by-side tracking of independent workflows.

  • Create Process Groups

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created with all the process participants. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

Example:

In this example, the default process group is updated with Hiring and Equipment Provisioning processes. As the process group contains more than one process, a connection is defined for these processes.

Then we create 2 process groups:

  • One group for Promotion Change
  • Another for Retirement

These are the independent process that are not related. For the individual processes, new process groups are created, one for each process. As there is only one process in each of these process groups, there no need to define the connection type.

 

  • Map Attributes for Unified Tracking

Once you’ve created process groups for your non-correlated processes, the next step is to unify how you view them. You can do them in the Attributes -> Context tab

Choose Map Attributes to map the attributes of the processes across process groups:

In the Map Attributes dialog box, select the Source Attribute and the Mapped Attribute from the drop-down list. You can map shared attributes like Employee ID or Department etc., The source attributes will then be visible in the Visibility Scenario Instances application and the Mapped Attributes are hidden.

You can choose Add Attribute button to map more attributes.

Choose Save.

This ensures all mapped attributes appear cohesively in your Visibility Scenario Instances application.

  • Finally release and deploy.

 

Business Value

Streamlined Monitoring: See all relevant processes, even if unlinked - in one dashboard.
Accurate Insights: Focus on meaningful groupings, not rigid process chains.
Scalability: Easily manage hybrid landscapes of connected and standalone processes.

 

Final Thoughts

The “No Correlation” feature in SAP Process Visibility is more than a technical enhancement, it’s a strategic enabler.
It empowers organizations to track and optimize processes the way they truly operate, not just how systems connect them.

Whether your workflows are integrated, hybrid, or standalone, SAP Process Visibility ensures you never lose sight of what matters most: business outcomes!

entry.title: Streamline Your Migration to SBPA with the ‘No Correlation’ Feature in Process Visibility
entry.content:
Introduction

As businesses modernise their operations, many customers are migrating from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA).

This migration is a key step in digital transformation, but it also introduces challenges when processes built on different technologies need to coexist and remain visible together.

That’s where SAP’s “No Correlation” feature in Process Visibility steps in, making it possible to track legacy and new processes in a unified view, without data duplication or reporting disruption.

 

The Migration Challenge

During migration, organisations often face:

  • Technology gaps between BTP Workflow and SAP Build Process Automation [SBPA] processes.
  • Disconnected visibility between legacy and new workflows.
  • Reporting inconsistency when both environments run in parallel.

 

How “No Correlation” Simplifies Migration to SAP Build Process Automation

Let’s say you’ve exported a Visibility Scenario “Insights on Capital Expenditure Process” from SAP Workflow Management and imported it into your SBPA project and you have re-modelled the process “Capital Expenditure Scenario” in SAP Build Process Automation as shown below:

Now, both your legacy Workflow and your newly built SBPA process serve the same business purpose, but run on different technologies.

By enabling “No Correlation” feature, you can:

  • Create separate Process Groups for each process participant (BTP Workflow & SAP Build Process Automation Process).
  • Use attribute mapping to unify common fields (e.g., Request Number, Employee ID etc.,).
  • Achieve a single, unified dashboard view in the Visibility Scenario Instances app.

 

Step-by-Step: Applying “No Correlation” for Migration to SAP Build Process Automation

  • Adding Process Participants:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor, add the Newly Modelled SBPA Process as a Process Participant:

  • Enable the Feature:

In your Visibility Scenario Editor → General tab → Enable “Visibility Scenario to Include Non-Correlated Processes”

  • Create Separate Process Groups
    • One for BTP Workflow from Workflow Management
    • One for SBPA Process
      Both run independently but share the same business context.

Note: A default Process Group is automatically created with all the process participants. You can edit or create new ones depending on your scenario.

  • Map Common Attributes

Under Attributes → Context tab, map shared business fields like Request ID, CAPEX cost, or Employee ID etc.,
This ensures seamless/unified view of both legacy and SBPA processes in a single Process Visibility dashboard.

Now that we have completed the configuration, the Source attributes would appear in the Process Visibility dashboard View and the Mapped attributes would be hidden.

 

Business Impact

Unified Process Visibility: Track historical (BTP Workflows) and new (SBPA processes) in one view.
Smooth Migration: Maintain operational reporting continuity during migration.
No Data Duplication: Map common attributes intelligently for consistent analytics.
Future-Ready Operations: Enable co-existence between multiple automation technologies on SAP BTP.

 

Final Thoughts

The “No Correlation” feature acts as a bridge during migration — helping organisations maintain visibility, accuracy, and performance as they move from SAP Workflow Management to SAP Build Process Automation.

It’s a practical example of how SAP’s intelligent automation tools ensure continuity while paving the way for innovation.

With “No Correlation” feature, you can confidently modernise your process automation landscape without losing sight of your data or insights.

The result is a clean, unified view in the Visibility Scenario Instances dashboard. This allows business users to continue tracking historical and newly migrated processes together, without disrupting reporting or analytics.

entry.title: Empowering Process Visibility with Step Navigation Links
entry.content:
Introduction

In the world of process automation and monitoring, visibility is power—but actionability is the real game-changer. That’s why SAP Process Visibility offers a powerful feature that lets you go beyond viewing process steps to actually interacting with them: Step Navigation Links.

With just one click, users can jump directly from a step in the Process Workspace to the relevant task in the source application [Eg., My Inbox, SAP Task Center etc.,] streamlining issue resolution, approvals, and decision-making.

Let’s explore how easy it is to set this up.

 

What Are Step Navigation Links?

Step navigation links allow you to embed deep links in specific steps of a process path so users can quickly navigate to external apps like My Inbox, SAP Task Center, or any custom application to take action or see more details.

This bridges the gap between process monitoring and process execution.

 

Real-World Example

Imagine you're tracking a Capital Expenditure Approval process in SAP Process Visibility. One of the steps is a pending task that a manager needs to approve in My Inbox.

With Step Navigation Links, you can:

  • Display a clickable link right on the process step in the Process Path view.
  • Direct users to the exact task instance in 'My Inbox'.
  • Eliminate the need for users to search manually or switch between systems.

 

How to Configure Step Navigation Links

A quick step-by-step guide to configure step navigation links in your visibility scenario can be found in our SAP Help Documentation : Configure Step Navigation Links.

 

Example: Deep Linking to My Inbox

Steps:

  • In the visibility scenario editor, navigate to the Processes tab and choose the SAP Build Process Automation process for which you want to configure step navigation link.
  • Under Steps and Events section, select the required step from the list and choose “Edit”.

  • In the Edit Step dialog box, navigate to the Link tab, and enable the Enable Link Configurations toggle button to configure the navigation link and update the Event, Path and Link Text as shown in the below example.

Here’s a practical example of how to create a dynamic link:

Copy the Original URL from 'My Inbox':

In the copied URL, replace the InstanceID with {stepInstanceId}, which will be dynamically retrieved from Process Visibility

Final URL:

This ensures that the link dynamically pulls the correct step instance ID when viewed in Process Visibility.

 

Why This Matters

Step Navigation Links bring real-time actionability to your process monitoring tools. Instead of just seeing that something is pending, users can click directly into the task, speeding up response times and improving collaboration across teams.

They’re especially valuable in scenarios like:

  • Procurement Approvals
  • HR Workflows
  • (Or) Any custom business process.

 

Final Thoughts

Configuring Step Navigation Links in SAP Process Visibility enables a dynamic, interactive experience. Whether you're managing tasks in My Inbox, SAP Task Center, or custom apps, these deep links let you act without leaving your process dashboard.

It’s a small setup with big impact—boosting productivity, responsiveness, and user satisfaction.

entry.title: Info/Links for TechEd Community Talk CT1293 - SAP Build Control Tower
entry.content:
This post is to provide additional reference information and links related to my community talk CT1293 - Get control of the control tower feature in SAP Build solutions. See you there.

Control Tower Layout

Here's is the current picture of the Control Tower.

I think the layout is simple and clean, though it has evolved with additional tiles over the last 2 years and I don't think it's so clear how everything is inter-related. Here is my annotated version with a few notes. 

My notes:

  • Environments, introduced relatively recently with the public environment deprecated, seems to me the central most-important tile on the page
  • Destinations and API keys are strongly connected to environments
  • The first 3 tiles are related to transport: The first defines whether the tenant is dev/qa/prod for the sake of transport, and the governance rules (next 2 tiles) in part add an extra layer of approval for transport operations. The rules also affect simply creating a project.

More information on the Control Tower: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-control-tower?locale=en-US

Permissions

There are many layers of permissions within SAP Build. Here they are from highest to lowest level.

IAS

Identity Authentication Service (IAS), or perhaps now just Cloud Identity Service, is the very first level and at the most basic level lets you create new users.

I just want to point out one helpful feature are groups. I can set up a group and then assign that group role connections. When I have a new user I just add them to the group and they inherent all the role collections. 

Here are groups in IAS.

Here I assign a group to a role collection. Note that SAP BTP does not have a dropdown of groups so you have to simply type in the name of the group.

YOu can do the same with attributes, for example, assign a role collection based on job function or home country.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-identity-services/cloud-identity-services/landing-page?locale=en-US

Tenants

Once you have a user in IAS, you can assign that user to a tenant and NOT assign them to other tenants. You can look in the Users page to see which users have access to the current tenant.

More information: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/business-users?locale=en-US

Roles

Once a user has access to the tenant in some way, you determine what they can do on that tenant by assigning them roles, not directly, but through role collections, which are sets of roles that loosely map to a persona (e.g., admin, developer, business user, super user).

Here's more information on the specific roles/role collections related to the low-code tools of SAP Build:

  • SAP Build Apps: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-apps/service-guide/configuring-user-roles?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Process Automation: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/authorizations?locale=en-US&q=role
  • SAP Build Work Zone: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-work-zone-standard-edition/sap-build-work-zone-standard-edition/about-roles-and-role-assignments?locale=en-US&q=role

Design-Time Authorizations

These authorizations are done on the project level, some know as collaboration authorizations, so you can work with others on specific projects.

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/managing-project-members?locale=en-US.

Runtime Automarizations

Runtime authorizations are the authorizations you have within environments. Environments are separate areas for deploying projects, and each environment can be set up to allow different users to do different activities (e.g., view, deploy, add users).

For information on the meaning of each role, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/share-environment.

Governance Rules

Governance rules let you set up a process to be executed so managers can approve or reject whether another user can create a project or transport a project.

If you enable rules for either creation or transport, you are automatically given into the lobby an out-of-the-box process and action. You must deploy the process before the rules can take effect (the action is automatically published). Before deploying, you can modify the process -- you really must since it the process automatically gives the requestor the right to approve his own project.

For more information, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build-service/build-service-guide/governance?locale=en-US&q=governance+rules.

Transport

Transport allows you to create formal processes for moving projects from one tenant to another tenant, generally from DEV > QA > PROD. The transport does not deploy projects but simply moves the design-time projects from one SAP Build installation to another. You can only transport a released version.

You will have to install Cloud Transport Manager Service, and add the Content Agent Service on every tenant to which you want to transport content. 

Once you have everything setup and execute a transport from the SAP Build lobby, the package goes to CTMS, where someone with the import role will need to approve the transport. 

For more information on setting up transport, see https://community.sap.com/t5/application-development-and-automation-blog-posts/transporting-content-in-sap-build-apps-sap-cloud-transport-management/ba-p/13737478.

For more information on how to transport and prerequisites, see https://help.sap.com/docs/build/sap-build-core/transport-project?locale=en-US&q=transport.
